Fighting for developers: As the home for all developers, GitHub is committed to shaping policies that promote their interests and the future of software. We work on policy in its many forms‚Äîlaws, regulations, norms, and standard practices‚Äîto fight for developers when it matters most.
Every developer has the right to do thei: No matter who they are or where they are, we believe developers should be able to work on the projects they care about. This means advocating for policies that promote developers‚Äô most basic rights: The rights to innovation, collaboration, and equal opportunity.

Innovation: Advocating for copyright, patent, and employment rules that foster exploration, collaboration, and the freedom to tinker on side projects.
Collaboration: Software development is a global exercise in teamwork. In order to innovate, build, and keep the world‚Äôs software secure, developers must be able to work together.
Equal Opportunity: Software development thrives in an open and inclusive environment. When everyone has equal access and opportunity to contribute, we all benefit.
Protecting open source from EU copyright: When the EU began working on the Copyright Directive in 2016, software developers weren‚Äôt on policymakers‚Äô minds. Drafts effectively required upload filters that would have wreaked havoc on online software collaboration. We worked to mobilize developers and convey their concerns to members of parliament, and together we succeeded: The final text included an exemption for ‚Äúopen source software developing and sharing platforms.‚Äù
Advancing developer freedom and access i: No matter where developers may live, we‚Äôre committed to keeping as much of GitHub available to as many developers as possible. As part of this commitment to support software development everywhere, we make the case to governments for licenses and changes to the law. Starting in 2019, we worked with the US government‚Äôs Office of Foreign Assets Control to obtain a license to fully serve developers in Iran. Building on this success, we‚Äôre pursuing similar efforts to be able to fully serve developers in Crimea and Syria, and are also advocating for changes to the law so that all developers can have access ‚Äî whether they use GitHub or other collaboration tools.
Establishing the Developer Defense¬†Fund: Section 1201 of the US DMCA can pose challenges to developers. Each year, GitHub receives a small number of 1201 takedown claims, contending that developers are hosting code that illegally circumvents a technological protection measure. To help, GitHub has committed $1 million to establish a Developer Defense Fund and sponsored the GitHub Developer Rights Fellowship at Stanford Law School‚Äôs Juelsgaard Intellectual Property and Innovation Clinic.
Platform responsibility: Protecting developers‚Äô ability to collaborate by providing a safe and inclusive space that transparently respects rights to free expression, assembly, and association.
Open source: Encouraging governments to use open source as a tool of public policy, to work proactively with open source contributors, and to support open source software in legislation and regulation.
Global collaboration: Supporting developers to work with anyone, anywhere, so they can build secure and useful software that benefits their local communities.
Inclusion: Breaking down barriers so anyone can become a developer and we can build a developer community that reflects our global diversity.
GitHub is leading the way for developers‚Äô rights worldwide. Our Policy team uses its voice to advocate for the developer community and shape policies that impact the software ecosystem as a whole.
Open an issue: Need help on a developer policy or want to share feedback?
Send us an email: Interested in collaborations or scheduling a meeting?
